awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: US-Ireland: Thermoelectric Concrete Envelope (ThermoConc)
awd_abstract_narration:
1805818 (Qu)/ 1805893 (Yin) 

With building heating and cooling systems accounting for a very significant portion of US energy consumption, a nation-wide focus is on developing renewable energy-based heating and cooling. While thermoelectric (TE) and solid state TE heat pumps (TEHP) are key options for energy generation, a significant gap remains in reducing inefficient system complexities. The objective of this project is to address the systems-level challenge by developing proof-of-concept TE concrete material that innately possesses TE properties and might result in an independent, comprehensive, and renewably sourced heating and cooling system. 

The international team for this project will leverage advances in thermoelectric materials, conductive concrete, and building model predictive control to create a three-in-one thermoelectric concrete, called ThermoConc, as a building envelope for electricity generation and space heating and cooling. The goal is to develop fundamental understanding of the characteristics, behaviors, operations, and controls of a thermoelectric generation and heat pumping system as an energy efficient means to both passively and actively control building interior temperature and harvest waste heat while enhancing human thermal comfort. Objectives will be to: 1) identify optimal design and control of ThermoConc and establish mathematical models for performance evaluation; 2) characterize the new TE concrete and evaluate the performance of ThermoConc both theoretically and practically; and 3) assess environmental and economic benefits and quantify energy-saving potentials of ThermoConc through full-scale testing and climate-sensitivity case study. The vision is that ThermoConc will facilitate savings in building sector energy consumption and accelerate adoption of 
renewable energy-based heating and cooling systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Buildings contribute 40% of global energy consumption, and 30-40% of this can be attributed to heating and cooling requirements [1]. Compared to traditional all-air heating, ventilation, and cooling systems, radiant heating, and cooling systems can save space, operate quietly, reduce energy consumption, and yield high levels of thermal comfort [2]. Current radiant heating technology typically uses air, water, or electricity to heat concrete floor slabs with high heat storage capacities. 

The research has studied the characteristics, behaviors, operations, and controls of a thermoelectric generation and heat pumping system as an energy-efficient means to control building interior temperature and harvest waste heat or renewable energy while enhancing human thermal comfort. The project outcomes advance science and engineering in thermoelectric materials, concrete composite, building science and thermal comfort.

The research advances radiant heating technology by cutting-edge thermoelectric concrete technology towards wall panels, which yield the quickest response time of any heating technology since they can be controlled individually. The collaborative research efforts aim to develop radiant wall heating systems through a thermoelectric building envelope. The thermoelectric building envelope (TBE) is a new active facade that integrates thermoelectric materials for space heating and cooling. Thermoelectric materials can convert electrical to thermal energy and vice versa. The conversion from thermal to electrical energy using thermoelectric material is called the Seebeck effect. Reversely, the same material can convert from electrical to thermal energy, named the Peltier effect. Thermoelectric technology, therefore, can provide heating or cooling by an electricity input in a heat pump mode (Peltier effect) and generate power when there is a temperature gradient in a power generation mode (Seebeck effect). The merits of TBE include a highly compact system design, no circulating medium needed for heating/cooling deliverables, and no refrigerant used for air conditioning, which can facilitate the operation of net-zero energy and CO2 emission buildings [5].

While this technology is in the early development phases, many questions remain unanswered regarding the human experience in a room with thermoelectric wall modules. Therefore, this research aims to evaluate the thermal comfort of a radiant heating thermoelectric building envelope (TBE) via computational fluid dynamics simulations. Advanced computational fluid dynamics (CFD) software incorporates the fundamentals of heat transfer to understand and assess thermal comfort alongside ASHRAE 55 standards [4].  

The small-scale TBE house testing and simulations proved that using the convective TBE can provide adequate heating to maintain indoor thermal comfort. The heating performance was better than an electrical heater. The project defined the environmental and economic assessment of the B as a building heating system and quantified the energy-saving potentials of TBE through the climate-sensitivity case study. The project provided fundamental insights regarding the holistic utilization of building envelope systems for renewable energy generation and thermal load supplement. The project addressed systems-level technical challenges needed to maximize the usage of concrete, reduce life-cycle costs, and improve environmental sustainability. The project provided a performance evaluation framework for TBE for energy, environment, and economics. 

The research has expedited the development of novel approaches, methodologies, and technology breakthroughs for building control to meet societal, environmental, technical, and economic needs. The proof-of-concept findings benefit occupied and unoccupied buildings, such as office, residential, and data storage facilities. Assessment analyses translate concrete suppliers and building stakeholders. The thermoelectric building envelope will facilitate savings in building sector energy consumption and accelerate the adoption of renewable energy-based heating systems. 

The international research team supported diverse students through new educational coursework, entrepreneurial training, and cross-cultural experiential learning. Graduates have contributed to a new workforce able to advance building sustainability. Outreach to diverse undergraduates has built awareness of and interest in STEM applications to sustainable and resilient buildings and informed STEM career trajectories.
